title: Dataset Project
text:
For my project, I decided to explore healthcare insurance data sets because I’m interested in understanding how medical conditions influence healthcare costs.


The pie chart below shows that diabetes was one of the most billed conditions at 16.8% of the total billing amount. A total amount billed of 2.385397e+08.
Additionally, the person with the highest bill was Karen Kline. She was billed a total 104746.064748 by United Healthcare in the span of 14 days











Name
kARen klInE    104746.064748
Name: Billing Amount, dtype: float64


I decided to understand how diabetes was being treated and how it would affect the cost. The table below shows that the number one insurance provider for people with Diabetes was Medicare with 1730 patients total. Additionally Medicare had the highest amount billed which could be due to the the fact that they had more patients.


Show the code
diabetes = df[df['Medical Condition'] == 'Diabetes']
df_unique = diabetes.drop_duplicates(subset='Name', keep='first')
insurance = df_unique['Insurance Provider'].value_counts()
print(insurance)

costly = df.groupby(df_unique['Insurance Provider'])['Billing Amount'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(5)


Insurance Provider
Medicare            1730
Blue Cross          1683
Cigna               1679
Aetna               1668
UnitedHealthcare    1624
Name: count, dtype: int64





Lipitor was the drug most likely prescribed to someone with diabetes. A reason for this is that people with diabetes are twice as likely to have heart disease or a stroke compared to people without diabetes. Medications such as Lipitor are effective at lowering low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol lowering the chances of a stroke.


Show the code
medication = diabetes['Medication'].value_counts()
plt.figure(figsize=(1, 1))
plt.bar(medication.index, medication.values)
plt.xlabel('Medication')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.title('Frequency of Medications')
plt.xticks(rotation=90) 
plt.show()











Show the code
costmed = df.groupby(diabetes['Medication'])['Billing Amount'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(5)

newdf = diabetes[['Medication', 'Insurance Provider', 'Billing Amount']]

medication_billing = newdf.groupby(['Insurance Provider', 'Medication'])['Billing Amount'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(8).reset_index()
print(medication_billing)


  Insurance Provider   Medication  Billing Amount
0           Medicare      Aspirin    1.076458e+07
1              Cigna      Lipitor    1.039165e+07
2              Aetna  Paracetamol    1.014584e+07
3              Aetna   Penicillin    9.897654e+06
4              Cigna   Penicillin    9.862867e+06
5         Blue Cross    Ibuprofen    9.843164e+06
6         Blue Cross      Lipitor    9.768164e+06
7           Medicare  Paracetamol    9.748423e+06


Liptor had second largest billed amount for medication under the insurance Cigna. In spite of Cigna having the third largest number of patients it was gaining the most amount of money by providing the Lipitor medication. Cigna was providing Lipitor medication at a higher amount than other insrance providers.


Show the code
cigna = diabetes[diabetes['Insurance Provider'] == 'Cigna']
med_admission = cigna.groupby('Medical Condition')['Admission Type'].value_counts()
plt.pie(med_admission, labels=med_admission.index, autopct='%1.1f%%')
plt.title('Admission Types by Medical Condition')
plt.show()

title: Brenda Cruz
text:
Hey, I’m happy you’re here

I’m currently a part of the LIFT Bioinnovation group working on setting up a computaional data course for UC Davis


Education

University of California, Davis
B.S in Biotechnology with a Specialization in Bioinformatics | Sept 2021 - June 2025 |
Contra Costa College | Sept 2019 - June 2021 |




Experience



UC Davis Analytical Laboratory January 2023 -- June 2024|Assistant Davis, CA

Assist laboratory technicians with 40+ soil measurements daily and performances of analysis on selected chemical constituents of soil, plant, water, and feed



Data Intensive Biology Lab June 2023 -- June 2024|Intern Davis, CA

Formulating experimental approaches to current questions in biotechnology; performance of proposed experiments.
Duties include quality analysis and control for sequencing data, assembling and annotating metagenomic reads, quickly comparing large sequencing datasets, document workflows using git and GitHub.

title: Brenda Cruz
text:
Biotechnology is a field that allows me to explore the life sciences while also engaging with the technological advancements shaping our world. Within biotechnology, my focus lies in bioinformatics, as a senior with experience in computational data, I have a solid foundation in data analysis from courses such as BIT150 and EVE 103 which introduced me to computational methods for analyzing genome-wide nucleotide sequences. Additionally, I am currently in a program called Hack the Hood based in Oakland, that delivers data science knowledge to inexperienced and disadvantaged groups. Through this experience, has empowered me to bring my knowledge back to the community.
About Me! →
